result.execSummary:
This case has not been concluded. Unless a judgment of conviction is entered, the defendant is presumed innocent of all charges.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.
result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Daniel J Downey

records.addlTxt:
8:38 AM Defendant Daniel J Downey in court, in custody.  Attorney Grant Ian Henderson in court for Daniel J Downey.  Prosecuting attorney Brian Van Schyndel in court for the State of Wisconsin. Digital Court Reporter: Hannah Wronkowski.  Defendant has been revoked.  State asks for one more status.  Defense asks for a trial date. State may be filing substantive motions and asks for a time for a final pretrial.  All Motions in Limine, Witness lists, Proposed Jury Instructions and changes to the Substantive Jury Instructions are due 48  hours before the Final Pretrial.  Parties are to check for witness availability for this scheduled trial date and inform the Court of any problems.

10:45 AM Defendant Daniel J Downey in court, in custody.  Attorney Grant Ian Henderson in court for Daniel J Downey.  Prosecuting attorney Brooke L Erickson in court for the State of Wisconsin. Court Reporter Mark Garvin. Defense asks for a PH. 
Defnse asks for a bond modification.  Defendant is on a hold.  Defendant would like the bond lowered in order to become an inmate worker. State has no comment. BTC: Bond modified to a $900 cash bond and a $4000 signature bond, same conditions.
